sentence: `HeaderSearch::loadTopLevelSystemModules` is a misnomer: It only loads the modulemap files in the system paths but it doesn't actually load the C++ modules behind them into the lookup. It's however a good idea to actually call this *in addition* to our code because it ensures that clang's module lookup is up to date. Can you remove the deletions in this patch, the rest is good to go. (For example this test fails now: https://epsft-jenkins.cern.ch/job/root-pullrequests-build/12169/testReport/projectroot.roottest.root.tree/addresses/roottest_root_tree_addresses_make/ )
author: root-project

author: root-project

sentence: `HeaderSearch::loadTopLevelSystemModules` is a misnomer: It only loads the modulemap files in the system paths but it doesn't actually load the C++ modules behind them into the lookup. It's however a good idea to actually call this *in addition* to our code because it ensures that clang's module lookup is up to date. Can you remove the deletions in this patch, the rest is good to go. (For example this test fails now: https://epsft-jenkins.cern.ch/job/root-pullrequests-build/12169/testReport/projectroot.roottest.root.tree/addresses/roottest_root_tree_addresses_make/ )
author: root-project

sentence: I think we want in general a function that makes a module with submodules available. We also could/should use that in `RegisterModule` to not invoke the parser there (which probably fixes some other problems too, thanks to @Axel-Naumann for this idea).

sentence: Thanks for the PR! I want to test the code soon (tensorboard is awesome!), but here already two issues you should address:. 1. Squash your commits into a single one (run `rebase -i HEAD~<number of commits` and squash them). 2. Fix the `clang-format` diff, go to the travis build (see below) and have a look at the job output. There should be a diff, which you can apply.

sentence: Hi! I've just tested the feature, really nice! But there's one problem on my system: You've activated the `write_images=False` option in the keras callback, but then I get the following error:. ```. InternalError (see above for traceback): PNG encoding failed. ```. I've compiled it without the enabled images, then everything runs fine. @pfackeldey Do you have an idea why it's failing on my system with the enabled images? Haven't found something by google.

sentence: because if it is not super useful, i would probably stick to the keras defaults:. ```. keras.callbacks.TensorBoard(log_dir='./logs', histogram_freq=0, batch_size=32, write_graph=True, write_grads=False, write_images=False, embeddings_freq=0, embeddings_layer_names=None, embeddings_metadata=None). ```. You've put these defaults:. ```. callbacks.append(keras.callbacks.TensorBoard(log_dir=" + logdir +. ", histogram_freq=1, batch_size=100, write_graph=True, write_grads=True, write_images=True)). ```. Why did you make these changes?

sentence: what is the difference between `histogram_freq=0` and `...=1`? I would like to know the reason for the options that differ from the default. I would set the `write_images` to `False`, because the current PyKeras interface is not desigend for image data. What about `write_grads`?

sentence: Thanks for your patch! On Mac 10.13.something with SIP enabled I get. ```. $ export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:/some/other. $ root -l -b. root [0] gSystem->Getenv("LD_LIBRARY_PATH"). (const char *) "/Users/axel/build/root/cmake/lib:/some/other". ```. According to your description I'd have expected that to be empty? Cheers, Axel.
author: root-project

sentence: Thanks for your patch! On Mac 10.13.something with SIP enabled I get. ```. $ export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:/some/other. $ root -l -b. root [0] gSystem->Getenv("LD_LIBRARY_PATH"). (const char *) "/Users/axel/build/root/cmake/lib:/some/other". ```. According to your description I'd have expected that to be empty? Cheers, Axel.

sentence: Thanks for your patch! On Mac 10.13.something with SIP enabled I get. ```. $ export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:/some/other. $ root -l -b. root [0] gSystem->Getenv("LD_LIBRARY_PATH"). (const char *) "/Users/axel/build/root/cmake/lib:/some/other". ```. According to your description I'd have expected that to be empty? Cheers, Axel.
author: root-project

sentence: Hi @Axel-Naumann, it is expected. Please see here: https://github.com/oracle/node-oracledb/issues/231. In the following case, bash is protected:. ```. $ export LD_LIBRARY_PATH='/xxx'. $ echo $LD_LIBRARY_PATH. /xxx. $ bash -c 'echo $LD_LIBRARY_PATH'. $. ```
author: root-project

sentence: Hi @Axel-Naumann, it is expected. Please see here: https://github.com/oracle/node-oracledb/issues/231. In the following case, bash is protected:. ```. $ export LD_LIBRARY_PATH='/xxx'. $ echo $LD_LIBRARY_PATH. /xxx. $ bash -c 'echo $LD_LIBRARY_PATH'. $. ```
author: root-project

sentence: OK - so why would ROOT need to fix that? Apple seems to argue that the env var needs to be re-exported in the sub-shell. Can you post a series of invocations that leads to a broken `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` environment that is symptomatic for the issue you are seeing?
author: root-project

sentence: > Apple seems to argue that the env var needs to be re-exported in the sub-shell. Thanks for the idea. I come up with a different (preferable) workaround. Could you give me a time to check the workaround works with CMake? I'll post the invocations if the workaround doesn't work.
author: root-project

sentence: Was TDirectory::Streamer actually used in the previous state? (i.e. rather than changing the using classes we ought to fix the 'new' code to be keep the old behavior ... so we need to understand why it worked :) )
author: root-project

sentence: Was TDirectory::Streamer actually used in the previous state? (i.e. rather than changing the using classes we ought to fix the 'new' code to be keep the old behavior ... so we need to understand why it worked :) )
author: root-project

sentence: > Was TDirectory::Streamer actually used in the previous state? No, custom streamer of TDirectoryFile does not invoke TDirectory::Streamer() method. > so we need to understand why it worked :). Some years ago sub-TDirectory was read via TKey::ReadObj() method. In the TKeyXML there is special post-processing for TDirectoryFile. Now subdirectory read through TKey::ReadObjectAny() method. And I just add post-processing code in TKeyXML::ReadObjectAny().
author: root-project

sentence: > No, custom streamer of TDirectoryFile does not invoke TDirectory::Streamer() method. Fair enough. But then I am confused ;) what changed?
author: root-project

sentence: > No, custom streamer of TDirectoryFile does not invoke TDirectory::Streamer() method. Fair enough. But then I am confused ;) what changed?
author: root-project

sentence: > Fair enough. But then I am confused ;) what changed? As I said, sub-directory was not working in TXMLFile already many years. While now GetObject() is called here:. https://github.com/root-project/root/blob/master/io/io/src/TDirectoryFile.cxx#L523. You can try to find in changes history of TDirectoryFile, when TDirectoryFile::GetObject() starts using of TKey::ReadObjectAny(). . Now I fix problem, which nobody care of (or nobody report when problem appeared).

sentence: > the problem is likely to be either at ... To be clearer. I suspect that __PRETTY_FUNCTION__ is returning for icc is different form that the one expected in TTypeNameExtractionBase::GetImpl and thus needs to be adjusted for it.
author: root-project

sentence: We need to stop relying on such hacks to deduce the types, because it will never work. If in the next version ICC decides to change the format of PRETTY_FUNCTION again, our code will become broken again. We need to use `typeid(T).name()` and then find a way to consistently demangle the name it returns, instead of trying to parse error messages.
author: root-project

sentence: > Remove unimplemented C++17 custom new/delete operators . Are you sure this is the right direction? As far as I know/recall those will actually be needed (to be implemented) to be complete/correct. (Not implementing them may lead to problem similar to those that lead to 0fc4f521b64c927977460253dc1e622eda431021 ... compilation works but behavior was incorrect). This 'dead' code was put there specifically as a reminder to implement those overloads when the time comes ....

sentence: > Are you sure this is the right direction? Yes and no. I first got ROOT to compile and work. That commit just allows to compile. Before the release we need to revert this and add back proper implementations of the custom `new/delete` operators so that we can track the memory. Having them there with the wrong signature and returning `nullptr` is actually worse than not having them, though. Whoever did that should have spent the extra hour or so of work to properly implement them instead.
author: root-project

sentence: > Having them there with the wrong signature and returning nullptr is actually worse than not having them, though. . Not having them leads to hard to track memory allocation/deletion mismatch in some cases. The best is indeed to have an implementation but a clear error (maybe throwing would be even better) is 'better' :)

sentence: >> root $ git grep 'not implemented' | wc -l. Most of these are a C++98 implementation of '=delete' to prevent copy of object. (i.e. hide/delete the copy constructors).
author: root-project

sentence: >> root $ git grep 'not implemented' | wc -l. Most of these are a C++98 implementation of '=delete' to prevent copy of object. (i.e. hide/delete the copy constructors).
author: root-project

sentence: >> root $ git grep 'not implemented' | wc -l. > Most of these are a C++98 implementation of '=delete' to prevent copy of object. (i.e. hide/delete the copy constructors). At least half of them are not comments, and at least 150 or so occurrences are for actual non-implemented stuff (i.e. inside a `Fatal` or `Error` call or something similar). I checked that afterwards.

sentence: I've now implemented the operator new and delete instead of just deleting them. If the build passes, I will merge this today so that others can try to build with C++17 enabled with Clang-5.0 to confirm that these changes are enough. Also, we need to decide if the commits on LLVM should be applied on their side first ot not. @vgvassilev @Axel-Naumann Please let me know.

sentence: @vgvassilev this breaks root.exe as there ROOT_MODULES isn't set. Also, the overlay file is already correctly set by rootcling [in this very well-written and not obsfuscated piece of code](https://github.com/root-project/root/blob/d34c7e5e8a99c0bf75ac315b3014f0f449b0595d/core/dictgen/src/rootcling_impl.cxx#L4332).
author: root-project

sentence: @Teemperor, why don't we put an extra check `!rootcling || rootcling && ROOT_MODULES`? This patch was supposed to fix an error that libc/stl cannot be found in rootcling stage2. PS: We will see if we need to reopen once PR #1394 lands.
author: root-project

sentence: We support `rootcling && ROOT_MODULES` and `rootcling && !ROOT_MODULES`, so not sure how the check would look like. Did you check that we have call `hdrSearchInfo.loadTopLevelSystemModules()` before `LoadModule`? Because the modulemap only contains libc/STL if you somehow get clang to parse it before.
author: root-project

sentence: We support `rootcling && ROOT_MODULES` and `rootcling && !ROOT_MODULES`, so not sure how the check would look like. sentence: Thanks for the comment @marsupial ! I'll make more tests with CP_UTF8. And the problem is appearing when deleting characters in the prompt (via backspace or del), the remaining of the line is filled with empty squares. So the issue is that ROOT is mixing unicode and non-unicode charaters. We will have to fix it
author: root-project

sentence: Thanks for the comment @marsupial ! I'll make more tests with CP_UTF8. And the problem is appearing when deleting characters in the prompt (via backspace or del), the remaining of the line is filled with empty squares. So the issue is that ROOT is mixing unicode and non-unicode charaters. We will have to fix it
author: root-project

sentence: Just a thought on how you're describing the issue:. Could it be the problem is not actually output, but the handling/deletion of a multi-byte UTF-8 character removing only one byte on the stream leaving an invalid UTF-8 encoded buffer?
author: root-project

sentence: The behavior shown in the failing test is not what we need, because the old `TGlobal` object claims it's valid but finding it by name returns a new one. I would not mind discussing whether returning a new `TGlobal` object from `GetListOfGlobals()->FindObject()` is a worthwhile backward incompatible change, but then the old `TGlobal` object must be told that it has been invalidated. Do you want to update the old `TGlobal` object and start that discussion? Or do you have a plan B?
author: root-project

sentence: The behavior shown in the failing test is not what we need, because the old `TGlobal` object claims it's valid but finding it by name returns a new one. I would not mind discussing whether returning a new `TGlobal` object from `GetListOfGlobals()->FindObject()` is a worthwhile backward incompatible change, but then the old `TGlobal` object must be told that it has been invalidated. Do you want to update the old `TGlobal` object and start that discussion? Or do you have a plan B?
author: root-project

sentence: I think we can modify TMVA::RandomGenerator as suggested in . https://stackoverflow.com/questions/25129500/using-stdshuffle-with-custom-rng. It would be probably better also not using the default_generator in the other cases, but either TMVA::RandomGenerator or std::mt19937 which are much better generators. . This I think is especially relevant for the DNN DataLoader. However, this is not urgent and for 6.12 we can keep the same functionality as before. We will need to fix this for 6.14 for the new DNN.
author: root-project

sentence: @etejedor mentioned that Spark calls `Aggregate` the exact same operation. Furthermore `accumulate` is already used in the STL to indicate a slightly different operation, so I think it would be okay to switch names. I also realized that there is an asymmetry that must be fixed:. the accumulator lambda can have signatures `U(U,T)` and `void(U&,T)` but the merge lambda can only take `U(U,U)`. I need to add `void(U&,U&)`. The use-case for the two first signatures is numerical operations on primitive types. The use-case for the two second signatures is accumulations in complex objects that are expensive or impossible to copy (e.g. accumulations of values into a histogram or graph).
author: root-project

sentence: > This is still used a lot. Isn't there a way to backport the external library to that version of gcc? I have no idea. . This library heavily uses c++11 and one special feature does not work in gcc 4.8. On the first place, JSON reading functionality I implement for ROOT7. Probably, it will be a waste of time trying to find solution for gcc 4.8.x, . which will disappear in next several years and not relevant for any new development.
author: root-project

sentence: @pcanal . I replace all C++ macros by templated methods. At least, it should produce smaller binary - some template methods can be reused. I also create correspondent tests . https://github.com/root-project/roottest/pull/118. And why building is failed - have no idea.

sentence: > While the latter sentiment can take us quite far, as one could even argue that imported libraries should carry whatever compiler definitions/options the client may need with themselves, unfortunately this is not super easy to do with CMake at the moment. (For instance I don't know of a good way in which the imported library could impose the same C++ standard on the client project that ROOT was built with. While allowing the client project to use an even newer standard if needed.). Hi @krasznaa, for the C++ standard have you see the "compile features" properties? AFAIK, that enforces the same standard on clients linking, unless they specify a newer one.
author: root-project

sentence: I have to admit, I didn't try this in detail... In the ATLAS code we set the C++ standard using the `CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD` cache variable. And as far as I understand from its documentation (https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.1/variable/CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD.html), its value is overridden by setting the `CXX_STANDARD` property explicitly on any target in the project. So what I'm worried about is a situation when for instance ROOT was compiled in C++14 mode, but I'd like to build my own code in C++17 mode. I **think** that setting `CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD` to 17, while I link to an imported library that carries `CXX_STANDARD=14` with it, will result in my own code being built in C++14 mode. But I should probably run some tests on it. Maybe I'm wrong...
author: root-project

sentence: I did a very quick test linking a test `example` target to an install of a `foo` project whose targets have the `cxx_auto_type` compile feature in their interface features (so C++11). When linking to these targets, I found:. 1) Just `target_link_libraries(example foo::foo)`, the `-std=c++11` flag is appended to the compilation flags of the `example` sources. 2) Adding `target_compile_features(example PUBLIC cxx_std_14)` uses `-std=c++14` in the flags. 3) Setting `CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD 14` instead of using `target_compile_features` has the same effect. The reverse also applies - linking to a C++14 imported target, but requiring C++11 in the project does result in C++14 flags applied to the compilation of the project (so behaviour is "newest standard wins").
author: root-project

sentence: Hi Ben,. Thanks for the info! This is very good to know, it should help with improving the ATLAS code as well in the future. Though I do wonder how much I want to become involved in tweaking the ROOT configuration... There are many things that I'd love to change about the current ROOT CMake configuration (I find it pretty bad that target properties are used so sparsely in the configuration, using directory level configurations in most cases instead.), but I wouldn't have time to propose an update for those that I'd like... As you probably saw, I didn't even try to alter the build-time behaviour of the code. I explicitly only modified the `INCLUDE_DIRECTORIES` property of the shared libraries for the installation. (As I didn't want to affect the include directory order on any of the targets, since I wasn't sure exactly how the directory properties would interact with the target properties.). So all in all, I'd just stay with fixing "this much" for now... Cheers,. Attila

sentence: >Though I do wonder how much I want to become involved in tweaking the ROOT configuration... There are many things that I'd love to change about the current ROOT CMake configuration (I find it pretty bad that target properties are used so sparsely in the configuration, using directory level configurations in most cases instead.), but I wouldn't have time to propose an update for those that I'd like... Hi Attila, thank you for the PR. Restructuring the build system is part of my work plan for the next year, so it's good to know that this is something that experiments will see as beneficial. I agree with you that we should be using target properties to propagate include directories and other settings that will allow dependent projects to simply add a `target_link_libraries()` call. This is one of the major motivations that we have for restructuring the build system.

Hi Attila, thank you for the PR. Restructuring the build system is part of my work plan for the next year, so it's good to know that this is something that experiments will see as beneficial. I agree with you that we should be using target properties to propagate include directories and other settings that will allow dependent projects to simply add a `target_link_libraries()` call. This is one of the major motivations that we have for restructuring the build system.
author: root-project

author: root-project

sentence: I have a general comment about adding this extra level of parallelism to the branch reading. While it might indeed help in cases where there is only one top-level branch that is split in sub-branches, it could also bring "too much" parallelism in some other cases. The performance of the top-level branch parallelism heavily depends on the granularity of the branches. For small branches, the creation of a task does not really pay off. I fear this problem might be exacerbated if we also operate in sub-branches. Moreover, as we offer it now, we won't have any way for the user to select how deep in parallelisation terms they want to go, meaning every time we run GetEntry with IMT on all the parallelism levels will be activated. On the other hand, another thing that hindered performance in the top-level branch parallelism was synchronization. Now there is one synchronization point per entry, which can be problematic if there is load unbalance (that is why we sorted the branches by time). Adding a second level of parallelism means we will have one more synchronization point per top-level branch and we don't know how this can impact performance.
author: root-project

sentence: I have a general comment about adding this extra level of parallelism to the branch reading. While it might indeed help in cases where there is only one top-level branch that is split in sub-branches, it could also bring "too much" parallelism in some other cases. The performance of the top-level branch parallelism heavily depends on the granularity of the branches. For small branches, the creation of a task does not really pay off. I fear this problem might be exacerbated if we also operate in sub-branches. Moreover, as we offer it now, we won't have any way for the user to select how deep in parallelisation terms they want to go, meaning every time we run GetEntry with IMT on all the parallelism levels will be activated. On the other hand, another thing that hindered performance in the top-level branch parallelism was synchronization. Now there is one synchronization point per entry, which can be problematic if there is load unbalance (that is why we sorted the branches by time). Adding a second level of parallelism means we will have one more synchronization point per top-level branch and we don't know how this can impact performance.

sentence: Hi,. indeed this is a behaviour I am observing. The parallelisation does take place but the time needed to go through a tree, therefore with the TTree::GetEntry parallelisation enabled, is increased. . On the other hand, this kind of approach could be a useful tool to increase the parallelism when reading trees with TTreeReader/TDF (more common in analysis than TTree::GetEntry). In addition, cases like the GeneROOT one would be addressed. Some things need to be understood, I think this demonstrator could be a starting point for a new pack of parallelisations we would like to see in ROOT.
author: root-project

sentence: Hi,. indeed this is a behaviour I am observing. The parallelisation does take place but the time needed to go through a tree, therefore with the TTree::GetEntry parallelisation enabled, is increased. . On the other hand, this kind of approach could be a useful tool to increase the parallelism when reading trees with TTreeReader/TDF (more common in analysis than TTree::GetEntry). Some things need to be understood, I think this demonstrator could be a starting point for a new pack of parallelisations we would like to see in ROOT.

sentence: Another aspect of the problem is the way in which nested parallelism is tackled. Given the current interface, TThreadExecutor, I think we are pushing all items of work in the global queue, therewith ignoring potential optimisations put in place by the scheduler.
author: root-project

sentence: What if the TBranchElement had an attribute to enable/disable parallelisation, just like the TTree does? This way we could disable the extra parallelism level of the branches from TTree::GetEntry, if we fear the parallelisation would be too fine grain, but still have it on for the TTreeReader/TDF cases that @dpiparo mentions?
author: root-project

sentence: This was a nice exercise which demonstrated that fine grained parallelism can be exploited easily for reading individual branches. The amount of areas which need further investigation cannot be tackled at the moment. I therewith propose to keep this PR in mind in the future when it will be necessary to parallelise reading within an individual branch and take home the lessons learned during the development of this code.

sentence: > Hopefully we can avoid them (or at least still be able to read older files). I also hope so. But after several more steps I will try to use text-based actions for XML - up to now binary actions are applied. And here one can have several details - like handling of STL containers. And if there are changes - this will be very difficult to handle - while binary actions will work directly with TBufferFile methods. . But let see...

sentence: The man pages look in general a bit outdated to me. I wonder if, without removing any credit to Paul for this nice PR, we still need them and we should not better focus all our documentation effort on a single source of information,
author: root-project

sentence: I will probably state a few obvious things:. - Maintaining a single documentation (like the web pages and doxygen) is better than having several (partially overlapping, partially complementing) documentations around. For maintenance and for users to know where to look. - If there is a man page it should be up to date (outdated information can be worse than missing man page, if there is no man page you look for other resources instead of wasting time with wrong information). Part of my motivation to make the update PR was that doing and merging the update is relatively straight forward and I can do part of the work for you. The possible deprecation and removal of the page is your business. - What I like about man pages wrt the full online documentation is: works w/o internet (imagine bad hotel wifi or overloaded conference wifi) and changing from the shell to a browser and clicking through 4 links, just to look up if it was `root -e 'std::cout << "hello world";'` or `-c`, is a mildly annoying hazzle. Having a short cli doc at hand at the cli is convenient. (This also means that the man page doesn't need to go beyond documenting the cli behaviour). - trying both `<command> --help` and `man <command>` to figure out which is available, is mildly frustrating. (That inconsistency is more a problem of all the software out there, and root can just catch that by having docs on both calls). So, my opinion: I'm fine if the man pages get removed for maintenance reasons (or possibly better get cut down to links to the forum and online doc). I would prefer if they stay (though tbh, I myself only use those for `root`, `root-config`, and `hadd`. And the one for `root-config` could even get shortened. e.g.: The "how to use root in a cmake project" is already findable on the web page, I haven't seen the same for bare make or autoconf as it's now in the man page).
author: root-project

(This also means that the man page doesn't need to go beyond documenting the cli behaviour). - trying both `<command> --help` and `man <command>` to figure out which is available, is mildly frustrating. (That inconsistency is more a problem of all the software out there, and root can just catch that by having docs on both calls). So, my opinion: I'm fine if the man pages get removed for maintenance reasons (or possibly better get cut down to links to the forum and online doc). I would prefer if they stay (though tbh, I myself only use those for `root`, `root-config`, and `hadd`. And the one for `root-config` could even get shortened. e.g.: The "how to use root in a cmake project" is already findable on the web page, I haven't seen the same for bare make or autoconf as it's now in the man page).

author: root-project

sentence: I will probably state a few obvious things:. - Maintaining a single documentation (like the web pages and doxygen) is better than having several (partially overlapping, partially complementing) documentations around. For maintenance and for users to know where to look. - If there is a man page it should be up to date (outdated information can be worse than missing man page, if there is no man page you look for other resources instead of wasting time with wrong information). Part of my motivation to make the update PR was that doing and merging the update is relatively straight forward and I can do part of the work for you. The possible deprecation and removal of the page is your business. - What I like about man pages wrt the full online documentation is: works w/o internet (imagine bad hotel wifi or overloaded conference wifi) and changing from the shell to a browser and clicking through 4 links, just to look up if it was `root -e 'std::cout << "hello world";'` or `-c`, is a mildly annoying hazzle. Having a short cli doc at hand at the cli is convenient. (This also means that the man page doesn't need to go beyond documenting the cli behaviour). - trying both `<command> --help` and `man <command>` to figure out which is available, is mildly frustrating. (That inconsistency is more a problem of all the software out there, and root can just catch that by having docs on both calls). So, my opinion: I'm fine if the man pages get removed for maintenance reasons (or possibly better get cut down to links to the forum and online doc). I would prefer if they stay (though tbh, I myself only use those for `root`, `root-config`, and `hadd`. And the one for `root-config` could even get shortened. e.g.: The "how to use root in a cmake project" is already findable on the web page, I haven't seen the same for bare make or autoconf as it's now in the man page).

sentence: Sure. This requires then to keep them updated and in sync with the developments of ROOT and the rest of the documentation. Is the price of all this adequate to the benefit?

sentence: Sorry, this is not true. The man pages include rootcling, hadd, talk about makefiles, root5, pq2 caches and many other things. This is not minimal maintenance. As a matter of fact, it is already outdated and this since a long while. . Here I am talking about improving documentation concentrating efforts on a single source of information, the total amount of work needed is the same but differently organised...

sentence: @Axel-Naumann. I implement several changes you requested:. - Use R__ERROR_HERE("WebDisplay"). - Move comments to implementation. - use std::vector as container (is it ok for potentially large queues of std::string?). - Hide THttpWSEngine from end-user; this is interface change; add to docu. - Few function signature changes in THttpWSEngine. I propose to merge this PR - it was rather bugfix PR and not redesign of THttpServer. Currently I want rather to continue with TWebDisplay and clients implementations

sentence: @linev, If we are sure about that then I can just remove them. Last PR I did was to fix a similar issue (https://github.com/root-project/root/pull/1491) where I was getting just Get() without any reference to `TTreeReaderValue`. There are a couple of Info() statements being used to give Warnings. Should we replace them with Warning statements?. Finally, there are one or two statements in which the Descriptor must change. Please check the comments on the code.

sentence: > Last PR I did was to fix a similar issue (#1491) where I was getting just Get() without any reference to TTreeReaderValue. This was different issue - at that place was subclass without dictionary. . In such case class name may be misleading. > There are a couple of Info() statements being used to give Warnings. Should we replace them with Warning statements?. . Not sure - there are many places in ROOT where warnings produced with Info() method. I would not change only one place because of that. > Finally, there are one or two statements in which the Descriptor must change. . > Please check the comments on the code. I recommend to close with PR and open new one, where only wrong method descriptor should be changed.
author: root-project

sentence: There is a problem in moving to https. Several systems (notably Macs) install curl without support for SSL, so if we move to https then all `-Dbuiltin_*` options will break.
author: root-project

sentence: There is a problem in moving to https. Several systems (notably Macs) install curl without support for SSL, so if we move to https then all `-Dbuiltin_*` options will break.

sentence: > Several systems (notably Macs) install curl without support for SSL. I can't speak beyond Macs here, but this hasn't been the case on macOS for quite a long time now. . It works just fine on macOS 10.10-10.13, and would be surprised if it didn't work down to at least 10.9. Some of the older versions of macOS struggle to handle newer ciphers/protocols/etc but any version of macOS released in the last 4 or 5 years should handle it.
author: root-project

sentence: > Several systems (notably Macs) install curl without support for SSL. I can't speak beyond Macs here, but this hasn't been the case on macOS for quite a long time now. . It works just fine on macOS 10.10-10.13, and would be surprised if it didn't work down to at least 10.9. Some of the older versions of macOS struggle to handle newer ciphers/protocols/etc but any version of macOS released in the last 4 or 5 years should handle it.

sentence: Should we note more explicitly the backward incompatibility introduced? (and/or should we reintroduce support for the old behavior). Namely this existing code:. ```. TH1::StatOverflows(kTRUE);. auto h = new TH1F(...);. h->Fill(); // many times . ```. will continue to work as expected by the user. But this code. ```. auto h = new TH1F(...);. TH1::StatOverflows(kTRUE);. h->Fill(); // many times . ```. will now change its behavior (i.e the call to StatOverflows will be ignored *silently*)
author: root-project

sentence: Hi,. Probably one should use three-state variable for TH1::SetStatOverflows. By default it is undefined and uses global setting (as before). Once called with true or false, any changes in global variables will be ignored. .

sentence: LLVM is technically patch free. We can teach our build system to try to find LLVM 5.0 and use it. The tricky part is that we still need to build clang (we should probably set the `LLVM_EXTERNAL_CLANG_SOURCE_DIR`).
author: root-project

sentence: I have moved all the code out of the `TString.cxx` file and it compiles. We can't do SFINAE in the template arguments because the signature of the function would be identical:. ```cpp. template<class T, class>. TString operator+(TString s, T i). ```. and . ```cpp. template<class T, class>. TString operator+(TString s, T u). ```. The only possible way is to do SFINAE in the return type, only because this is a case of multiple SFINAE overloads and not just one function that has substitution failure. Putting it in the return type also allows the declaration and definition to be separate.
author: root-project

sentence: I've noticed that there is no use of `Char_t` anywhere in these two files and that `char` is being used instead. I thought that ROOT preferred using the types defined in `RTypesCore.h` or is this not true? Also, there is no Issues section on the GitHub. Where is the discussion taking place? Is it only here, where people submit changes?
author: root-project

sentence: @peremato is right, since the changes of this PR are only executed if the Python version is >= 3. After discussing it together, we could make it possible by having:. - ROOT externals for Python3. - A CMake option to specify a minimum Python version to look for. We need to check the second point with @amadio once he is back.
author: root-project

sentence: @peremato is right, since the changes of this PR are only executed if the Python version is >= 3. After discussing it together, we could make it possible by having:. - ROOT externals for Python3. - A CMake option to specify a minimum Python version to look for. We need to check the second point with @amadio once he is back.
author: root-project

sentence: I am sorry, but I do not think we can merge this. The artificial dependency also means that things that don't need to be rebuilt if you modify files will be rebuilt after this change. My machine is not so powerful and I never had problems with this, except for when using ICC and building multiple sources of ROOT at the same time with 4 threads each.
author: root-project

sentence: The macos failure are unrelated and 'seem' to be due to an environment setup problem. The error is not finding the davix library:. ```. +Error in <TInterpreter::TCling::AutoLoad>: failure loading library libRDAVIX.so for TDavixFile. +cling::DynamicLibraryManager::loadLibrary(): dlopen(/Volumes/HDD2/ec/build/workspace/root-pullrequests-build/build/lib/libRDAVIX.so, 9): Library not loaded: libdavix.0.dylib. + Referenced from: /Volumes/HDD2/ec/build/workspace/root-pullrequests-build/build/lib/libRDAVIX.so. + Reason: image not found. ```. and loading on the machine running 'setup.sh' and thisroot.sh lead to inconsistent results. ```. cd /Volumes/HDD2/ec/build/workspace/root-pullrequests-build/roottest/root/io/webfile. root.exe -b -l -q runCloseTWebFile.C. Processing runCloseTWebFile.C... ```. succeeds whereas the jenkins builds failed this test. Loading the library explicit also works:. ```. macitois19:build sftnight$ root.exe -b -l . gSroot [0] gSystem->Load("libRDAVIX.so"). (int) 0. ```. but running rootls fails. ```. macitois19:build sftnight$ /Volumes/HDD2/ec/build/workspace/root-pullrequests-build/build/bin/rootls -1 http://root.cern.ch/files/pippa.root. cling::DynamicLibraryManager::loadLibrary(): dlopen(/Volumes/HDD2/ec/build/workspace/root-pullrequests-build/build/lib/libRDAVIX.so, 9): Library not loaded: libdavix.0.dylib. Referenced from: /Volumes/HDD2/ec/build/workspace/root-pullrequests-build/build/lib/libRDAVIX.so. Reason: image not found. Error in <TInterpreter::TCling::AutoLoad>: failure loading library libRDAVIX.so for TDavixFile. cling::DynamicLibraryManager::loadLibrary(): dlopen(/Volumes/HDD2/ec/build/workspace/root-pullrequests-build/build/lib/libRDAVIX.so, 9): Library not loaded: libdavix.0.dylib. Referenced from: /Volumes/HDD2/ec/build/workspace/root-pullrequests-build/build/lib/libRDAVIX.so. Reason: image not found. WARNING: File http://root.cern.ch/files/pippa.root does not exist. ````
author: root-project

The error is not finding the davix library:. ```. +Error in <TInterpreter::TCling::AutoLoad>: failure loading library libRDAVIX.so for TDavixFile. +cling::DynamicLibraryManager::loadLibrary(): dlopen(/Volumes/HDD2/ec/build/workspace/root-pullrequests-build/build/lib/libRDAVIX.so, 9): Library not loaded: libdavix.0.dylib. + Referenced from: /Volumes/HDD2/ec/build/workspace/root-pullrequests-build/build/lib/libRDAVIX.so. + Reason: image not found. ```. and loading on the machine running 'setup.sh' and thisroot.sh lead to inconsistent results. ```. cd /Volumes/HDD2/ec/build/workspace/root-pullrequests-build/roottest/root/io/webfile. root.exe -b -l -q runCloseTWebFile.C. Processing runCloseTWebFile.C... ```. succeeds whereas the jenkins builds failed this test. Loading the library explicit also works:. ```. macitois19:build sftnight$ root.exe -b -l . gSroot [0] gSystem->Load("libRDAVIX.so"). (int) 0. ```. but running rootls fails. ```. macitois19:build sftnight$ /Volumes/HDD2/ec/build/workspace/root-pullrequests-build/build/bin/rootls -1 http://root.cern.ch/files/pippa.root. cling::DynamicLibraryManager::loadLibrary(): dlopen(/Volumes/HDD2/ec/build/workspace/root-pullrequests-build/build/lib/libRDAVIX.so, 9): Library not loaded: libdavix.0.dylib. Referenced from: /Volumes/HDD2/ec/build/workspace/root-pullrequests-build/build/lib/libRDAVIX.so. Reason: image not found. Error in <TInterpreter::TCling::AutoLoad>: failure loading library libRDAVIX.so for TDavixFile. cling::DynamicLibraryManager::loadLibrary(): dlopen(/Volumes/HDD2/ec/build/workspace/root-pullrequests-build/build/lib/libRDAVIX.so, 9): Library not loaded: libdavix.0.dylib. Referenced from: /Volumes/HDD2/ec/build/workspace/root-pullrequests-build/build/lib/libRDAVIX.so. Reason: image not found. WARNING: File http://root.cern.ch/files/pippa.root does not exist. ````

sentence: As @ellert points out, we need to port jsmva to d3 v4 that jsroot uses. Right now jsmva is basically unusable; Most of it's functionality depends on d3. Incorporating this PR will allow most of jsmva functionality to run, but a few things will be missing due to an api change. I suggest to integrate this PR as is and provide the update to the rest of jsmva in a separate PR (unless you @ellert would volunteer to update this PR). Details (and for future reference):. There are a few places of jsmva that should be updated to run under d3.v4. The swan example . `https://cern.ch/swanserver/cgi-bin/go?projurl=https://raw.githubusercontent.com/iml-wg/tmvatutorials/master/TMVAinJupyter_FullTutorial.ipynb` shows what is broken. The problems arise when calling:. - BookDNN (interactive design of DNN's; does not render). - DrawNerualNetowork (visualising NN's; does not render). - DrawDecisionTree (visualising BDT's; does not render). - DrawCutEfficiencies (curves come up in grayscale, should be in color). List of changes for 3 -> 4 can be found here: https://github.com/d3/d3/blob/master/CHANGES.md#changes-in-d3-40. Important ones to note are:. - d3.svg.line -> d3.line. - d3.svg.diagonal -> _removed_
author: root-project

The swan example . `https://cern.ch/swanserver/cgi-bin/go?projurl=https://raw.githubusercontent.com/iml-wg/tmvatutorials/master/TMVAinJupyter_FullTutorial.ipynb` shows what is broken. The problems arise when calling:. - BookDNN (interactive design of DNN's; does not render). - DrawNerualNetowork (visualising NN's; does not render). - DrawDecisionTree (visualising BDT's; does not render). - DrawCutEfficiencies (curves come up in grayscale, should be in color). List of changes for 3 -> 4 can be found here: https://github.com/d3/d3/blob/master/CHANGES.md#changes-in-d3-40. Important ones to note are:. - d3.svg.line -> d3.line. - d3.svg.diagonal -> _removed_

The problems arise when calling:. - BookDNN (interactive design of DNN's; does not render). - DrawNerualNetowork (visualising NN's; does not render). - DrawDecisionTree (visualising BDT's; does not render). - DrawCutEfficiencies (curves come up in grayscale, should be in color). List of changes for 3 -> 4 can be found here: https://github.com/d3/d3/blob/master/CHANGES.md#changes-in-d3-40. Important ones to note are:. - d3.svg.line -> d3.line. - d3.svg.diagonal -> _removed_
author: root-project

sentence: As @ellert points out, we need to port jsmva to d3 v4 that jsroot uses. Right now jsmva is basically unusable; Most of it's functionality depends on d3. Incorporating this PR will allow most of jsmva functionality to run, but a few things will be missing due to an api change. I suggest to integrate this PR as is and provide the update to the rest of jsmva in a separate PR (unless you @ellert would volunteer to update this PR). Details (and for future reference):. There are a few places of jsmva that should be updated to run under d3.v4. The swan example . `https://cern.ch/swanserver/cgi-bin/go?projurl=https://raw.githubusercontent.com/iml-wg/tmvatutorials/master/TMVAinJupyter_FullTutorial.ipynb` shows what is broken. The problems arise when calling:. - BookDNN (interactive design of DNN's; does not render). - DrawNerualNetowork (visualising NN's; does not render). - DrawDecisionTree (visualising BDT's; does not render). - DrawCutEfficiencies (curves come up in grayscale, should be in color). List of changes for 3 -> 4 can be found here: https://github.com/d3/d3/blob/master/CHANGES.md#changes-in-d3-40. Important ones to note are:. - d3.svg.line -> d3.line. - d3.svg.diagonal -> _removed_
author: root-project

sentence: This doesn't work properly on the build nodes... ```. 13:58:21 -- Found PythonInterp: /usr/bin/python3.4 (found version "1.4") . 13:58:21 -- Found PythonLibs: /cvmfs/sft.cern.ch/lcg/views/LCG_rootext20171122/x86_64-ubuntu1404-gcc48-opt/lib/libpython2.7.so (found version "2.7.13"). ```. We probably have to stick with setting `PYTHON_EXECUTABLE` in Jenkins, due to the non-standard location of Python from the externals.

sentence: @etejedor If with have `python=ON` as default, then it will be possible to pass only `-Dpython_version=2.7` in the CMake command line. Reading the `FindPythonInterp.cmake` that comes with CMake, I'm not sure how to pass a minimal version. The only thing the documentation mentions is using `${Python_ADDITIONAL_VERSIONS}` to look for specific versions. Adding a minimum version implies repeating in ROOT some of the code in `FindPythonInterp.cmake`, but it can be done.
author: root-project

sentence: Hi @etejedor - I ran into some issues with some of the scripts, I think they are mainly due to incomplete translations from C root to pyroot. How would you like to handle these? Shall I create issues in JIRA? Or shall I just list things here and you help? One example: https://github.com/root-project/root/blob/master/tutorials/roofit/rf107_plotstyles.C#L69 - `ROOT.RooAbsData.None` should work since `dir()` shows it, but in https://github.com/clelange/root/blob/roofit_tutorial/tutorials/roofit/rf107_plotstyles.py#L62 gives `SyntaxError: invalid syntax`.
author: root-project

sentence: Hi @etejedor @dpiparo - I've implemented all your requests. Now all files should have the desired header, the `if __name__ == "__main__":` parts are removed, and whenever there are print statements, I've made sure that they are compatible with both python2 and 3. Remaining issues:. - Not working: 107, 109, 508. - 513 has invalid PDF. - 80X fail with `malloc: *** error for object xxx: pointer being freed was not allocated` - but work in general, it's just because of the `ROOT.gDirectory.Add(mcs)` statements at the end. I would nevertheless suggest to (squash) merge all this now so that we can actually see the generated notebooks etc. This would make it easier for others to contribute and fix things as well. I'll create JIRA issues in the next couple of days for the problems in 107, 109, 508.
author: root-project

sentence: Hi @etejedor @dpiparo - I've implemented all your requests. Now all files should have the desired header, the `if __name__ == "__main__":` parts are removed, and whenever there are print statements, I've made sure that they are compatible with both python2 and 3. Remaining issues:. - Not working: 107, 109, 508. - 513 has invalid PDF. - 80X fail with `malloc: *** error for object xxx: pointer being freed was not allocated` - but work in general, it's just because of the `ROOT.gDirectory.Add(mcs)` statements at the end. I would nevertheless suggest to (squash) merge all this now so that we can actually see the generated notebooks etc. This would make it easier for others to contribute and fix things as well. I'll create JIRA issues in the next couple of days for the problems in 107, 109, 508.
author: root-project

sentence: Hi @clelange, thank you for creating the JIRA tickets. Regarding the PR, after discussing with @dpiparo we believe it would be best if:. - The tutorials that are failing are not included now in the PR. - Those failing tutorials are attached to the corresponding JIRA tickets and we will add them later when the issues are understood and fixed. Could you then remove the failing tutorials from this PR so that we can go ahead with the merge? As you said, we will also check how the notebook version looks like and more small fixes can come later.

sentence: However, you will need to ask to build with `@phsft-bot build with flags -Dbuiltin_zlib=ON` to test both values of the flag, as by default is should be using the system one on Linux and Mac.

sentence: I will fix warnings, but linking failures on centos7 and ubuntu seems to be not connected with zlib, but with linking of jpeg lib for asimage:. ```. 12:28:23 [7743/9574] Linking CXX shared library lib/libASImage.so. 12:28:23 FAILED: lib/libASImage.so . 12:28:23 : && /usr/bin/c++ -fPIC -pipe -m64 -Wshadow -Wall -W -Woverloaded-virtual -fsigned-char -fPIC -pthread -std=c++11 -g -Wl,--no-undefined -shared -Wl,-soname,libASImage.so -o lib/libASImage.so graf2d/asimage/CMakeFiles/ASImage.dir/G__ASImage.cxx.o graf2d/asimage/CMakeFiles/ASImage.dir/src/TASImage.cxx.o graf2d/asimage/CMakeFiles/ASImage.dir/src/TASPluginGS.cxx.o -Wl,-rpath,/cvmfs/sft.cern.ch/lcg/views/LCG_rootext20171122/x86_64-ubuntu1604-gcc54-opt/lib:/mnt/build/workspace/root-pullrequests-build/build/lib: lib/libAfterImage.a /cvmfs/sft.cern.ch/lcg/views/LCG_rootext20171122/x86_64-ubuntu1604-gcc54-opt/lib/libfreetype.a /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libgif.so /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libtiff.so /cvmfs/sft.cern.ch/lcg/views/LCG_rootext20171122/x86_64-ubuntu1604-gcc54-opt/lib/libpng.so -l /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libjpeg.so /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libSM.so /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libICE.so /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libX11.so /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libXext.so lib/libZLIB.a lib/libGraf.so lib/libHist.so lib/libMatrix.so lib/libMathCore.so lib/libImt.so lib/libRIO.so lib/libThread.so lib/libCore.so && :. 12:28:23 /usr/bin/ld: cannot find -l/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libjpeg.so. 12:28:23 collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status. ```
author: root-project

sentence: Hi Danilo, does the last commit mean that the standard `std::not_fn` fails to pass the test? I saw that the backport headers has guards against C++17 and Windows. How about adding an else clause and still running the test by including the standard `std::not_fn`?
author: root-project

sentence: Hi Danilo, does the last commit mean that the standard `std::not_fn` fails to pass the test? I saw that the backport headers has guards against C++17 and Windows. How about adding an else clause and still running the test by including the standard `std::not_fn`?
author: root-project

sentence: > Jokes apart, redoing the tutorial is easy. As a matter of fact, I'll add soon to the PR. Great thanks. Could you also translate threadsh2.C? Thanks. PS. ```. (*gThreadXAR)("METH", 4, arr, NULL);. ```. means, please execute the given function call as part of the main threads 'ProcessEvents' loop.

sentence: The test h2 shows how to generated animated gif from snapshots of the canvas without taking a lock (but by using the gThreadXAR mechanism ... which we probably need to (eventually) 'replace'). If there is no easy and/or clear translation of this example, I recommend we keep it until such a time where we have a clear replacement. Thanks,. Philippe.

sentence: As per failed tests, the new logic fails to recognize variable length arrays in some cases. Maybe @pcanal can suggest what is the right condition to check to distinguish between scalars and arrays (we don't care about the difference between fixed and variable length, that's taken care of transparently by `TTreeReaderArray`).

sentence: @bluehood - if any of the `TLeaf`s of the branch contains a `fLeafCount`, then it is a variable-sized array. So, you want to look and see if `GetLeafCount()` returns `nullptr`; if so, it is fixed-size. The number of fixed-sized elements is returned by `GetLen()`. Note that `fNdata` appears tempting to use, but it's only computed on the leaf's read.
author: root-project

sentence: @bluehood - if any of the `TLeaf`s of the branch contains a `fLeafCount`, then it is a variable-sized array. So, you want to look and see if `GetLeafCount()` returns `nullptr`; if so, it is fixed-size. The number of fixed-sized elements is returned by `GetLen()`. Note that `fNdata` appears tempting to use, but it's only computed on the leaf's read.
author: root-project

sentence: @bbockelm thanks. Could you please double-check the following pseudo-code? ```c++. TLeaf *l = GetALeaf();. if (l->GetLeafCount() != nullptr) {. // this is a variable-sized array. } else if (l->GetLen() > 1) {. // this is a fixed-sized array. } else {. // l->GetLen() == 1 and this is a single element. }. ```
author: root-project

sentence: @bbockelm thanks. 1. `TTreeReader` does not support multiple leaves per branch, so TDF does not either. 2. what does it mean to have a `fLeafCount` _and_ a `GetLen() > 1`? Is it a variable-sized array or a fixed-sized array? Or a variable-sized array of fixed-sized arrays, in which case I have no idea how `TTreeReaderArray` would handle it?
author: root-project

sentence: > The number of fixed-sized elements is returned by GetLen(). You meant GetLenStatic. GetLen is the 'effective' number of element and is including the leaf count information, it gives information about the entry last read (via GetEntry). So. ```. TLeaf *l = GetALeaf();. if (l->GetLeafCount() != nullptr) {. // this is a variable-sized array. } else if (l->GetLenStatic() > 1) {. // this is a fixed-sized array. } else {. // l->GetLen() == 1 and this is a single element. }. ```. > It's possible to have more than one leaf per branch. Very rare, however (I believe one has to do this fairly explicitly in the internals of ROOT?). It is not that rare. Any code not supporting must be instrumented to explicitly print a error and/or warning message when the case is encountered.
author: root-project

sentence: @pcanal what's the difference between `GetLenStatic` and `GetLen`? why are all these super-important methods undocumented?
author: root-project

sentence: > why are all these super-important methods undocumented? 'because' the code is ancient :( .... and there is some sparse documentation. TLeaf::GetLen has a one len documenation and GetLenStatic is trivial get for fLen (yes, the name don't match :( ) which has a documentation line. In summary the extent of the doc is:. ```. GetLenStatic : Number of fixed length elements. GetLen : Return the number of effective elements of this leaf. ```. And effectively we have the relationship:. ```. GetLen() == ( GetLenStatic() * variableDimensionSize ). ```
author: root-project

GetLenStatic : Number of fixed length elements. GetLen : Return the number of effective elements of this leaf. ```. And effectively we have the relationship:. ```. GetLen() == ( GetLenStatic() * variableDimensionSize ). ```
author: root-project

sentence: @pcanal in the end we always use `TLeaf::GetCount` (never `TLeaf::GetCounter`) together with `GetLenStatic` to find out if the branch is an array and, if it is, what we should put as a counter in the leaflist. In particular we get the counter like this:. ```c++. leaf->GetLeafCount() ? std::string(leaf->GetLeafCount()->GetName()) : std::to_string(leaf->GetLenStatic());. ```. which seems to work for the cases supported by `TTreeReaderValue`: one single leaf per branch, either a fixed-sized or a variable-sized unidimensional array.
author: root-project

In particular we get the counter like this:. ```c++. leaf->GetLeafCount() ? std::string(leaf->GetLeafCount()->GetName()) : std::to_string(leaf->GetLenStatic());. ```. which seems to work for the cases supported by `TTreeReaderValue`: one single leaf per branch, either a fixed-sized or a variable-sized unidimensional array.
